When it rains, it pours! From new contracts, to race news, to a jam-packed UCI post-meeting press release yesterday â€” itâ€™s been a pretty full-on week.Â 

Plus, we have Giro Rosa news at last, and itâ€™s looking promising. I wonâ€™t be holding my breath just yet but the â€˜under new managementâ€™ sign is up and the renovation looks pretty nice through the window so far.

Elsewhere, Olympic selections are trickling through and thereâ€™s live womenâ€™s racing on again this weekend at the first ever Tour de Suisse women. Loads to get through so letâ€™s have itâ€¦

NewsÂ ğŸ“°

  • As mentioned, the new organisers of theÂ Giro RosaÂ (nowÂ Giro dâ€™Italia Donne), PMG/Starlight, held a presentation yesterday to outline their plans for the race and present the stages. They then released a media package complete with a provisional startlist (!!) and details of each stage. The promise of live coverage was reiterated, more details are set to come over the next few weeks. For now, you can check out a previewÂ here.Â 
  • Buried within all of that Giro dâ€™Italia Donne news was the revelation thatÂ Annemiek van VleutenÂ is â€œundecidedâ€ on whether to race in Italy or not. She had previously named the race as a goal this season but toldÂ Cycling NewsÂ that she is now looking to focus on preparing for the Olympic Games.Â 
  • In other calendar/race news: as part of a wide-ranging press release following a Management Committee meeting, the UCIÂ set out the calendar for 2022Â which included the news thatÂ Ride LondonÂ will now become a three day event,Â Ceratizit Challenge by La Vueltaincreases from three to four stages, the 6-dayÂ Battle of the NorthÂ is on, and theÂ Tour de France FemmesÂ is official at eight days starting right after the menâ€™s Tour. Lots to look forward to!
  • It was a full-on meeting, as the UCI also announced that they will be giving sanctioning powers to theirs Ethics Commission (without having to wait for a decision by the Disciplinary Commission Ã  laÂ the case of Marc Bracke) to combat abuse in the sport. This came after a series of recommendations made byÂ The Cyclistsâ€™ Alliance.
  • Last one from the busy bees in Aigle: the 2022 team selection process for WWT races will include the 15 WWT teams (there are meant to be 15 next year) who gain automatic entry, as will the two best Continental teams. A move which the UCI hope will â€œstimulate the development of womenâ€™s teams.â€
  • Lucinda BrandÂ has re-signed with both her road team,Â Trek-SegafredoÂ and cyclocross team,Â Baloise Trek Lions,Â for two more years.
  • In other contract news,Â Lotte KopeckyÂ has signed a three-year contract with SD Worx until 2024.Â 
  • This weekÂ Drops-Le Col s/b TempurÂ officially confirmed thatÂ their riderÂ Joss LowdenÂ will attempt an hour record in Grenchen, SwitzerlandÂ this September after unofficially breaking the record in training in February.Â 
  • The Transcontinental RaceÂ ultra-endurance even has been postponed due to Covid-19 once again, the race will now be pushed back to 2022.Â 
  • Marlen ReusserÂ has been selected to represent Switzerland for road at the Tokyo Olympic Games. The 29-year-old came second at the World ITT champs last year so will be one to watch against the clock next month.Â 
  • Liv RacingÂ announced this week that the teamÂ will part ways with ex-pro and performance managerÂ Lars BoomÂ with immediate effectÂ after Boom signed a contract with a different, unnamed, squad for 2022.Â 
  • Barbados national championÂ Amber JosephÂ will guest ride for L39ION of Los Angeles.Â She will make her debut at the Armed Forces Cycling Classic in Virginia this weekend.Â 
  • Two for two in the Stripping Dictatorships of Track Events stakes. After the UEC championships were moved out of Minsk last week, theÂ 2021 UCI Track Cycling World ChampionshipsÂ â€” due to be held from the 13th-7th October â€” have been moved from Turkmenistan to Glasgow. Although this time the reason given was that: â€œat the request of their organisers, as the health constraints and restrictions linked to the Covid-19 pandemic make it impossible to stage the event in the countryâ€â€” which is odd coming from the home of a dictator thatÂ denies the existence of Covid.

Results ğŸ†

  • Jolanda NeffÂ took theÂ Swiss national MTB XCOÂ title on Sunday ahead ofÂ Alessandra KellerÂ andÂ Sina Frei.Â Jacqueline Schneebeliwon the U23 race whileÂ Monique HalterÂ claimed the junior title.
  • TheÂ Austrian MTB XCOÂ title was won byÂ Mona MitterwallerÂ ahead ofÂ Laura StiggerÂ andÂ Anna Spielmann.Â ClaraÂ SommerÂ took the junior title.

Lots on this weekend!Â

Itâ€™s technically not this week, but I came across the link toÂ this webinar. You might remember the bookÂ RevolutionsÂ byÂ Hannah RossÂ from a few weeks ago. Cycling-adjacent story of the week ğŸ‘°ğŸ¤µ

This one even manages to tie in dogs as well as bikesâ€¦

If you didnâ€™t know, (why should you?) singerÂ Ariana GrandeÂ got marriedrecently and, as a wedding gift, animal charityÂ PETAÂ sent herâ€¦ a â€˜vegan tandem bikeâ€™. The charity didnâ€™t explain what makes a bike veganÂ but they did say: â€œGrande has been outspoken about animal rights since she first rose to stardom, and late last year, she launched Orange Twins Rescue, an effort to spay, neuter, and find homes for dogs and cats in the Los Angeles area. PETA was delighted to see that while the happy coupleâ€™s ceremony only included a few close friends and family members, they, of course, made room for Grandeâ€™s own adopted dogs.â€

Sadly, there were no images of the dogs or the bike.Â
